bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, September 18, 1890

div1.p: Lazear writes about his trans-Atlantic voyage. He arrives safely in New York and will travel to Baltimore soon.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, September 18, 1890
div1.p:
Our voyage is now
nearing the end as we are expected
to reach New York tomorrow.
I have not written anything before
because all I could have
said would have been to
record the state of the weather.
We have had a great variety
of weather. The first two days
after passing Boulogue were
very fine. We could see the
chalk - hills near Dover and
the Isle of Wight, It then began
to roughen up, the wind increasing
for two days and ending in
a hurricane which shook us
about at a lively rate for a
night and a day. It was
impossible to sleep on account
of the rolling. In rough weather
before this, I could be zig-
zag with knees bent and in
that way keep still and get to
steep. But this night the
rolling was so bad that I
slid back and forth bumping
against the side of the bunk.
It was really a very severe
storm. It took a day for the
sea to quiet down and then
a fog come on which lasted
for thirty-six hours. The whistle
was blown at short intervals
all the time. Yesterday we
had another gale which lasted
all night and the sea is still
high from the effects of it.
I have been perfectly well
throughout the voyage and Norris
was only seasick the morning
after the hard night.
The passengers are rather
uninteresting especially the
female portion. Mr. Fetedoux
however is a very pleasant
jolly man. I have been able
to do a little reading.

We arrived today at one o'clock
and I am now at Mrs. Denison's
I received your letter. I had
intended to telegraph but you
are at Windsor now and
I know that the delivery
is uncertain there. However
I think I will telegraph to Aunt Kate
care of the Car line.

I will try to get over to Baltimore
to-morrow. I will first go
up to the college to get your
letter. And then I will have
to go to the bank.
